text:
We’ve made it to the last stop of the Speaking
of Chemistry California Road Trip.

But to quote one of the world’s greatest
scientists, “Where we’re going, we don’t
need roads.”

Let’s dive into some atmospheric chemistry
with Kimberly Prather of UC San Diego and

the Scripps Institution of Oceanography to
learn more about the mysterious connection

between the sea and the sky, including how
bacteria help make it rain.
Literally.

Kim: Very little is known about what actually escapes
from the ocean right now.
Matt: Well, that’s a short episode.
JK, you guys.
JK.

Researchers don’t completely understand
the chemistry of what the ocean dispatches

into the atmosphere, but they do know there
are lots of compelling reasons to study it.

Kim, for instance, looks at the composition
of aerosol particles in the atmosphere and

the relationship of that chemistry to weather
and climate.

When people think of aerosol particles in
the sky, they usually think of soot, the small,

carbon-rich chunks that come from burning
fuels like wood and gasoline.

Soot shows how dark particles in the atmosphere
can absorb radiation from the sun and warm
up the planet.

But there are also natural aerosols: dust
from deserts, particles formed with the help

of fragrant terpene compounds from forests,
and, if you’ll permit me to be glib, crud
from the ocean.

These natural particles can contribute
to global heating and cooling, too, and they
play an important role in precipitation as well.
More on that in a minute.

When it comes to sources of natural aerosols, though,
Kim’s really interested in the ocean because

it makes up more than 70% of the Earth and
so much of its chemistry is still a mystery.

To try and change that, she founded a research
facility called CAICE, or the Center for Aerosol

Impacts on Climate and the Environment, if
you’re not into the whole brevity thing.

CAICE is this huge lab that literally brings
the ocean inside.

This let’s Kim and her colleagues to study
the sea in a more controlled fashion than
is possible in the wild blue yonder.
So here’s what we know so far.
The ocean sprays salt into the sky.
Not a big surprise.

But most of what the sea sends up is actually
organic material, things like proteins, lipids,
and even bacteria.
And it’s everywhere.

Kim: There’s a really thin layer--it’s almost
like a thin skin--that coats the entire surface
of the ocean.
It’s less than a millimeter thick.
There’s lot of hydrophobic organic material.

Matt: The ocean can easily kick this stuff out
into the air through waves crashing and air
bubbles bursting.

When it comes to bacteria, though, the ocean
isn’t throwing things out willy nilly.

The ocean appears to shoot certain bacteria
out preferentially and Kim’s trying to figure
out which bacteria go airborne using genetics.

Kim: Right now, we’re looking at the selective
transfer.

We’re trying to see what DNA and RNA is
in the seawater versus what gets launched.
And so the question is why.

Matt: That’s a tantalizing mystery and it gets
even sweeter when you know that certain bacteria,

such as Pseudomonas syringae, can actually
help make it rain.

The ocean and other natural sources can actually
launch bacteria high enough up into the atmosphere

to join other aerosol particles that help
ice crystallize and form clouds, you know,
rainmakers.

Kim: At the center of every cloud drop, at the
center of every ice crystal is a particle.

Only one in a million particles in the atmosphere
will actually form an ice crystal.

And there’s something very, very magical
of the chemistry of those particles that do

and that’s the big question that chemists
right now are really, really work hard to
try and answer.

Matt: And the chemistry of natural aerosols could
be particularly magical.

Atmospheric chemists, including Kim, recently
joined forces with meteorologists and found

that storm clouds grown naturally with bacteria
and desert dust appear to drop more precipitation

than clouds seeded with other aerosols, such
as those from pollution.

Understanding the chemistry of natural aerosols
could therefore help us humans learn to grow

better rain clouds, which is actually something
we’ve working on since the 1940s.
Sean Connery, you may remember, even dabbled in the 1998 documentary, “The Avengers.”
But even without this sci-fi-esque application, it’s still pretty rad that we’re finding

new connections between the natural systems
on our planet.

Kim: I think people are starting to realize that
there’s much more of a coupling between

the meteorology and the atmospheric chemistry
than people ever believed before.

But that is a brand new area of research that
we have a long ways to go.

Huge thanks to Kim and Jyllian Kemsley, who
actually conducted the interview you saw with Kim.

Jyllian’s covered a lot of atmospheric chemistry
for C&EN and we’ve shared some of our favorite
stories in the description below.

And, lastly, huge thanks to all of you out there
watching.

We had a blast on this road trip and we hope
you did too.

Check out the entire trip in this playlist
and hit us up in the comments with suggestions
for who we should visit next.
